newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asia Product Swaps- June gas oil up on cash trades.
newsitem.headline: Asia Product Swaps- June gas oil up on cash trades.

text.p: Singapore June gas oil swaps firmed at midday Friday after Thursday's cash purchases by a Japanese trader supported the prompt market and widened the June/July differential, traders and brokers said.
Brokers said the spread between June and July prices has widened to around 30 cents from 15 cents seen on Thursday.
June gas oil swaps were last quoted at $25.30/$25.45, up from at least 20 cents from Thursday quotes at $25.00/$25.10.
July was last seen at $24.95/$25.10 up marginally from Thursday's $24.85/$24.95.
Traders said the widened spread between the two months were triggered by Marubeni International Petroleum Co purchase of 600,000 barrels of gas oil on Thursday.
The company bought a total of four gas oil cargoes at between $25.10 and $25.35 per barrel for end-May to mid-June lifting on a free-on-board basis.
The purchases brought some relief to sellers who were previously concerned that prices may fall below the $25.00 per barrel support in the cash market.
"I would be happy if Thursday's buying would be repeated today," said one potential seller.
But some traders remained cautious, citing the low awards seen in the recent Taiwan and Sri Lanka tenders and high stocks in Singapore.

Fuel oil was last quoted at $101.00/$102.00, unchanged from Thursday quotes. But a firm undertone, supported by fresh demand and fewer exports from the Middle East, may pull prices up further, traders said.
The crude market provided very little direction to guide swaps quotes, traders said.
The prompt June contract on ACCESS were last quoted at $21.27, down a marginal three cents from its last official close.
Overnight crude values for the June contract on IPE were downed a marginal seven cents at $19.44 per barrel as the contract expired Thursday.
